{{distinguish|Quarrystone}} [[Image:Quernupper.jpg|thumb|The upper stone of a Scottish hand quern from [[Dalgarven Mill]], North Ayrshire]] [[File:जाँतो.jpg|thumb|An ancient tool used to grind food items in [[Nepal]]]] [[File:Jato An ancient tool used to grind food item in Nepal.ogv|thumb|Nepali women using quern-stones to grind a food item]] '''Quern-stones''' are [[Rock (geology)|stone]] tools for hand-[[Grinding (abrasive cutting)|grinding]] a wide variety of materials. They are used in pairs. The lower, stationary, stone is called a '''quern''', while the upper mobile stone is called a '''handstone'''. The central hole is called the '''hopper''' and a '''handle slot''' enables the handstone to be rotated.<ref name="McLaren113p106">{{cite journal | authors = McLaren D, Hunter F| year = 2008 | title = New aspects of rotary querns in Scotland| journal = Proc Soc Antiq Scot | volume = 113 | pages = 106 | ISSN = 0081-1564 | url =}}</ref> They were first used in the [[Neolithic]] era to grind cereals into flour.<ref name="britmus">{{cite web | url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe/q/quern_stone_for_making_flour.aspx | title=Explore/Highlights: Quern stone for making flour |publisher=The British Museum | location=London |archive-date=April 21, 2009 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421031008/https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe/q/quern_stone_for_making_flour.aspx}}</ref>
==Uses of quern-stones== An old Gaelic proverb is "''The quern performs best when the grindstone has been pitted.''"<ref>{{cite book |author=Burnet, Graeme Macrae | year = 2015 | title = His Bloody Project|edition=First | publisher = Contraband | location = Glasgow | isbn = 9781910192146 | page = II}}</ref>
===Design of quern-stones=== The upper stones were usually concave whilst the lower was convex and sometimes a [[Millrind|rind]] was present as a piece of wood etc that allowed the cereal etc to be added but still acted as a centering device. The upper stone sometimes had a cup shaped area around the hopper hole with a raised edge.<ref>{{cite journal | authors = McLaren D, Hunter F| year = 2008 | title = New aspects of rotary querns in Scotland| journal = Proc Soc Antiq Scot | volume = 138 | pages = 106 | ISSN = 0081-1564 | url =}}</ref> Most handstones have a handle hole on the upper surface, however one class of quern-stones have a slot handle which indicates that a piece of wood was placed horizontally and protruded out from the edge so that the operator could turn the stone by standing and using a rod vertically.<ref>{{cite journal | authors = McLaren D, Hunter F| year = 2008 | title = New aspects of rotary querns in Scotland| journal = Proc Soc Antiq Scot | volume = 138 | pages = 112 | ISSN = 0081-1564 | url =}}</ref> One class of upper quern-stones has from two to three sockets for the rod used to turn them and this is thought to reflect the need to reduce wear and tear by having alternative points of contact when in active use.<ref name="McLaren115">{{cite journal | authors = McLaren D, Hunter F| year = 2008 | title = New aspects of rotary querns in Scotland| journal = Proc Soc Antiq Scot | volume = 115 | pages = 106 | ISSN = 0081-1564 | url =}}</ref>
===Grain=== [[Image:Cliffecastlemus 016.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Revolving beehive quern-stones and [lower] a saddlestone on display at [[Cliffe Castle Museum]], [[Keighley]].]]
Quern-stones have been used by numerous civilizations throughout the world to grind materials, the most important of which was usually [[cereal|grain]] to make [[flour]] for [[bread]]-making. They were generally replaced by [[millstone]]s once mechanised forms of [[Mill (grinding)|milling]] appeared, particularly the [[water mill]] and the [[windmill]], although animals were also used to operate the millstones. However, in many non-Westernised, non-mechanised cultures they are still manufactured and used regularly and have only been replaced in many parts of the world in the last century or so.
In early [[Maya civilization]]s the process of [[nixtamalization]] was distinctive in that hard, ripe kernels of maize (corn) were boiled in water and lime, thus producing nixtamal which was then made into unleavened dough for flat cakes by grinding with a handstone on a quern (''metate'').<ref>{{cite book |author=Coe, Michael D. | year = 1999 | title = The Maya|edition=Sixth | publisher = Thames & Hudson | location = New York | isbn = 0-500-28066-5 | page = 13}}</ref>
Quern stones were used in [[China]] at least 10,000 years ago to grind wheat into flour. The production of flour by rubbing wheat by hand took several hours.<ref>{{Cite book |title=The Technology of Ancient China |last= Greenberger |first= Robert |publisher=Rosen Publishing Group |year=2005 |isbn=978-1404205581 |pages=10}}</ref> Due to their form, dimensions, and the nature of the treatment of the surfaces, they reproduce precisely the most ancient implements used for grinding cereal grain into flour. Saddle querns were known in China during the Neolithic Age but rotary stone mills did not appear until the Warring States Period.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Science and Civilisation in China: Volume 6, Biology and Biological Technology, Part 5, Fermentations and Food Science |last=Huang |first=H.T. |publisher= Cambridge University Press |year=2000 |isbn=978-0521652704 |volume=6 |publication-date=November 30, 2000 |page=463}}</ref> A prehistoric quern dating back to 23,000 BCE was found at the Longwangchan archaeological site, in Hukou, Shaanxi in 2007. The site is located in the heartland of the northern Chinese loess plateau near the Yellow River.<ref>{{Cite book |title=The Archaeology of Early China: From Prehistory to the Han Dynasty |last=Shelach-Lavi |first=Gideon |publisher= Cambridge University Press |year=2015 |isbn=978-0521145251 |publication-date=January 26, 2015 |page=53}}</ref>
===Other materials=== As well as grain, ethnographic evidence and [[Mesopotamian]] texts shows that a wide range of foodstuffs and inorganic materials were processed using stone querns or mortars, including nuts, seeds, fruit, vegetables, herbs, spices, meat, bark, pigments, temper and clay.<ref>Wright 1992:87f</ref> Moreover, one study analysing quern-stones noted that a number of querns had traces of [[arsenic]] and [[bismuth]], unlike their source rocks, and had levels of [[antimony]] which were ten times higher than those of the rocks. The authors concluded that this was probably due to the use of these querns in the preparation of medicines, cosmetics, dyes or even in the manufacture of alloys.<ref>Lease et al. 2001:235</ref>
Querns were widely used in grinding metals ores after mining extraction. The aim was to liberate fine ore particles which could then be separated by washing for example, prior to smelting. They were thus widely used in [[gold mining]] in antiquity.
In the [[Shetland]]s tobacco was not smoked when first introduced, but instead was ground up into [[Snuff (tobacco)|snuff]], and inhaled up the nose. Snuff-querns consisted of an upper and lower stone, fixed together by a central iron pivot. The quern was held on the user's lap, the eye of the quern was filled with dried tobacco leaves, and then the upper-stone was turned using the handle. The friction caused by the turning ground the leaves into a fine powder that built up around the edge of the lower-stone. Many snuff-querns had a small hole or cut made near the edge of the upper-stone, into which a pointed end of a lamb's horn was placed in order to turn the stone; an alternative to using a handle.<ref>[http://www.scran.ac.uk/000-000-591-022-C Snuff Quern. Accessed | 2009-11-20]</ref>
===Incidental uses=== [[Image:Quern-stones in China small.jpg|thumb|right|150px|A stack of quern-stones for sale in a market in [[Haikou]], [[Hainan]], [[China]]. These quern-stones are only about 30 cm wide.]] There are, however, more surprising recorded uses of quern-stones. For example, DeBoer, in his review of the traditional gambling games of North American tribes, reports that one of the games involved bouncing a group of split canes off a quern.<ref>DeBoer 2001:223.</ref>
Violence is recorded in the [[Book of Judges]] (9:53; [[NRSV]]): “But a certain woman threw an upper-millstone on [[Abimelech (Judges)|Abimelech]]’s head, and crushed his skull.”
==Manufacture of quern-stones== The best type of stone from which to manufacture quern-stones are [[igneous]] rocks such as [[basalt]]. These have naturally rough surfaces, but grains do not detach easily, so the material being ground does not become gritty. However, such rocks are not always available, meaning that quern-stones have been manufactured from a wide variety of rocks, including [[sandstone]], [[quartzite]] and [[limestone]]. Quernmore Crag near [[Lancaster, Lancashire|Lancaster]] in England is named after the quarrying of millstone grit used to make quern stones in these parts.
Rutter was able to show, for the southern Levant, that basalt quern-stones were preferred to those manufactured from other rock types. Basalt quern-stones were therefore transported over long-distances, leading him to argue that, despite their every-day, utilitarian function, they were also used as a [[status symbol]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Rutter|first=Graham|title=Basaltic-rock procurement systems in the southern Levant|date=2003|publisher=PhD thesis, University of Durham|page=236|url=http://0lem.wordpress.com/2011/06/16/basalt-procurement/|accessdate=12 March 2014}}</ref>
Research in Scotland has indicated that to a degree regional styles existed.<ref name="McLaren">{{cite journal | authors = McLaren D, Hunter F| year = 2008 | title = New aspects of rotary querns in Scotland| journal = Proc Soc Antiq Scot | volume = 138 | pages = 122 - 125 | ISSN = 0081-1564 | url =}}</ref>
==Evolution of quern-stones== [[Knocking stone]]s were used in the preparation of small quantities of cereal however the earliest forms of quern were the saddle and trough querns. The earliest quern so far discovered dates to c. 9,000 BCE and was found at Abu Hureyra, Syria.<ref name="britmus"/> A later development was the rotary quern, which takes several forms.
===Saddle quern=== The saddle quern is produced by rocking or rolling the handstone using parallel motions (i.e., pushing and pulling the handstone), which forms a shape looking like a [[saddle]]. These are the most ancient and widely used type of quern-stone and were superseded around the 5th to the 4th century BC by the more efficient rotary quern.<ref>{{cite journal | authors = McLaren D, Hunter F| year = 2008 | title = New aspects of rotary querns in Scotland| journal = Proc Soc Antiq Scot | volume = 138 | pages = 105 | ISSN = 0081-1564 | url =}}</ref> The handstones for saddle querns are generally either roughly cylindrical (not unlike a [[rolling pin]]) and used with both hands, or rough hemispheres and used with one hand. This provides a crushing motion, not a grinding action and is more suitable for crushing malted grain. It is not easy to produce flour from a saddle quern with unmalted grain. The handstone is also referred to as a 'rubber' or 'mouler'.<ref>MacSween, A & Sharp, M (1989), ''Prehistoric Scotland.'' London : B.T.Batsford. {{ISBN|0-7134-6173-X}}. p. 17.</ref>
===Rotary hand quern=== As the name implies, the rotary quern used circular motions to grind the material, meaning both the quern and the handstone were generally circular. The handstone of a rotary quern is much heavier than that of saddle quern and provides the necessary weight for the grinding of unmalted grain into flour. In some cases the grinding surfaces of the stones fit into each other, the upper stone being slightly concave and the lower one convex.
====Beehive quern==== [[File:Quern stones.JPG|left|thumb|190px|<center>Querns from the [[Whithorn]] Museum]]In this type the upper stone is hemispherical, or bun-shaped, with a central conical hopper to hold the grain that falls down a hole to the grinding surface. It is held in position with a pivot that fits into a central hole in the bottom stone. The upper stone also has a deep horizontal socket in its steep side in which to place the wooden peg used as a handle to rotate or oscillate the upper stone. This was the earliest type of rotary quern to appear in the British Isles. It arrived in Britain in the middle of the Iron Age (about 400-300 BC) and spread into the northern half of Ireland, probably from Scotland, some time after the 2nd century BC.<ref name="J.T. Koch, 2007 p. 150">J.T. Koch, ''An Atlas for Celtic Studies'' (2007), p. 150.</ref>
====Disc quern==== [[Image:Handquern1.jpg|right|thumb|190px|<center>A hand quern being operated<ref name="Garnett155">Garnett, T. ''Observations on a Tour through the Highlands and part of the Western Isles of Scotland, particularly Staff and Icolmkill.'' Pub. T. Cadell. The Strand. P. 155.</ref>]]
The adjustable, discoid rotary quern has larger, flatter and more discoid stones than the beehive type. The lower stone was completely perforated. The long handle rotated in a shallow socket in the upper surface of the upper stone. They are thought to have originated in [[Spain]] 2,500 years ago<ref name="Ritti et al. 2007, 159">{{harvnb|Ritti|Grewe|Kessener|2007|p=159}}</ref> and appear to have arrived in maritime Scotland from about 200 BC with people who built the defensive homes known as [[broch]]s. This Iron Age type closely resembles the adjustable Highland quern still in use in historic times.<ref>E.W. MacKie, The broch cultures of Atlantic Scotland: origins, high noon and decline: part 2: The Middle Iron Age: high noon and decline c.200 BC – AD 550, ''Oxford Journal of Archaeology'', vol. 29, no 1. (2010), pp. 89-117 (100).</ref>
[[File:Girl with ponytail-Women at the Quern.jpg|thumb|left|The quern rests on the [[earasaid]] of the woman on the right, possibly to catch grain; she feeds the stone with grain from the bowl at her left. Woodcut from [[Thomas Pennant]]'s 1772 book ''A Tour in Scotland''.]]
Garnett in his 1800 tour of Scotland describes the use of a hand quern as follows: "The quern consists of two circular pieces of stone, generally grit or granite, about twenty inches in diameter. In the lower stone is a wooden peg, rounded at the top; on this the upper stone is nicely balanced, so as just to touch the lower one, by means of a piece of wood fixed in a large hole in this upper piece, but which does not fill the hole, room for feeding the mill being left on each side: it is so nicely balanced, that though there is some friction from the contact of the two stones, yet a very small momentum will make it revolve several times, when it has no corn in it. The corn being dried, two women sit down on the ground, having the quern between them; the one feeds it, while the other turns it round, relieving each other occasionally, and singing some Celtic songs all the time."<ref name="Garnett155"/>
====Miniature quern==== Under 200mm in diameter and varying from roughly dressed to carefully worked, often with vertical handle sockets, a new class of querns has been identified having been overlooked in the past as weights, etc. In all respects they are like full sized quern stones and they show the typical wear signs that indicate that they were used for grinding small amounts of seeds, minerals or herbs. A suggestion that they may have been made as toys is thought to be unlikely.<ref name="McLaren2008">{{cite journal | authors = McLaren D, Hunter F| year = 2008 | title = New aspects of rotary querns in Scotland| journal = Proc Soc Antiq Scot | volume = 138 | pages = 119 - 122 | ISSN = 0081-1564 | url =}}</ref>
===Other types of quern stones=== Other forms of quern-stone include hopper-rubbers and Pompeian mills, both used by the [[Ancient Rome|Romans]]. The larger rotary mills were usually worked by a donkey or horse via an extension arm of wood attached to the upper stone. [[File:Roman mill.ogg|thumb|right|Sound of a Roman mill.]] {{Commons category|Ancient Roman mills}}
==Laws against use== There was a legal requirement in [[Scotland]] for tenants to pay for use of the baron's mill. Early leases of mills gave to the miller the legal right to break quern-stones which were being used in defiance of [[thirlage]] agreements.<ref name="Gauldie">Enid Gauldie, ''The Scottish Miller 1700–1900''(John Donald 1981), {{ISBN|0-85976-067-7}}.</ref>
The obligations of thirlage eventually ceased to apply, but thirlage in Scotland was only formally and totally abolished on 28 November ([[Martinmas]]) 2004 by the [[Abolition of Feudal Tenure etc. (Scotland) Act 2000]].<ref>[http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20080810012035/http://www.opsi.gov.uk/legislation/scotland/acts2000/en/00en05-a.htm ]</ref>
Similar requirements existed and were enforced actively in England.<ref>[http://www.robinthewood.co.uk/Quernsm%20-&-Mill-Stones.html Querns and millstones] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080917050138/http://www.robinthewood.co.uk/Quernsm%20-%26-Mill-Stones.html |date=September 17, 2008 }}</ref>
==Ornament and inscription== A number of handstones have been found with extra carving however it is not always straightforward to separate decoration from practical functional purposes. The designs invest in the appearance of the handstone when it is in circular motion and the ability of the quern-stones to change seeds into flour may invoke a feeling of transformative magic that attracted both reverence and status to these household objects.<ref name="McLaren119">{{cite journal | authors = McLaren D, Hunter F| year = 2008 | title = New aspects of rotary querns in Scotland| journal = Proc Soc Antiq Scot | volume = 119 | pages = 106 | ISSN = 0081-1564 | url =}}</ref> Three beehive querns found in Ireland have inscribed ornament of [[La Tène]] type,<ref name="J.T. Koch, 2007 p. 150"/> as do examples from England and Wales.<ref name="McLaren113p117">{{cite journal | authors = McLaren D, Hunter F| year = 2008 | title = New aspects of rotary querns in Scotland| journal = Proc Soc Antiq Scot | volume = 113 | pages = 117 | ISSN = 0081-1564 | url =}}</ref> Many of the horizontal slot-handled quern-stones have decoration that usually follows the basic pattern of motifs that encircle the hopper and/or the handle slot. One type though has an irregular pattern of cup marks that encircle the hopper.<ref name="McLaren113p106" />
A quern was discovered at [[Dunadd]] in Scotland which has a cross carved into the upper stone. The cross has expanded terminals and ultimately derives its form from [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] and [[Byzantine]] predecessors of the fifth and sixth centuries. This example has a high quality of finishing which reflects its 'cost' and enhances its symbolic value and social significance. The cross is likely to have 'protected' the corn and the resultant flour from evil, such as fungal [[Rust (fungus)|rust]] or [[ergot]]. Various legends give miraculous power to mill-stones and several have been found which have been re-used in the construction of burial cists or as tomb stones. The association between quern stones and burial may be because they are used in the process of making bread, the staple of life. A broken or disused quern therefore can be seen as symbolic of death.<ref name="Campbell">Ewan Campbell, A cross-marked quern from Dunadd and other evidence for relations between Dunass and Iona, ''Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland'', vol. 5, no. 117 (1987), pp. 105 - 117.</ref> In [[Clonmacnoise]], near [[Athlone]] in County Offaly in [[Ireland]], a quern stone was found which had been made into a tombstone, having been ornamented and the name Sechnasach, who died in 928 AD, inscribed onto it.<ref name="Bord">Janet and Colin Bord, ''Mysterious Britain'' (Garnstone 1973), {{ISBN|0-85511-180-1}}. P. 62.</ref> A large quern was discovered on the [[Lough Scur]] [[crannog]] in [[Ireland]].
==The Wondrous Mauchline Quern== In the 9th century the Welsh monk [[Nennius]] wrote a history of Britain, the ''[[Historia Brittonum]]'', in which he lists the thirteen wonders of Britain, and included in it is the wondrous '[[Mauchline]] Quern' that ground constantly, except on Sundays. It could be heard working underground and the local placename 'Auchenbrain' may celebrate it, translating from the Gaelic as 'field of the quern''.<ref>Watson, William J. (1926). ''The History of the Celtic Place-Names of Scotland''. Edinburgh : William Blackwood & Sons Ltd., p.187</ref>

{{short description|Belgian journalist, writer, underwater archeologist and the first aquanaut. }} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} '''Robert Pierre André Sténuit'''<ref name="ISC">{{cite web |url=http://www.shipwreckconference.org/conference_bios2.htm |title=International Shipwreck Conference |year=2011 |accessdate=August 30, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111010005804/http://www.shipwreckconference.org/conference_bios2.htm |archivedate=October 10, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> (born 1933 in [[Brussels]])<ref name="Sténuit 1">{{cite book |first=Robert |last=Sténuit |title=Treasures of the Armada |others=Trans. Francine Barker |publisher=[[E. P. Dutton|E. P. Dutton & Co]] |location=New York City |year=1973 |page=283 |isbn=0-525-22245-6}}</ref> is a Belgian journalist, writer, and [[underwater]] [[archeologist]]. In 1962 he spent 24 hours on the floor of the [[Mediterranean Sea]] in the submersible "Link Cylinder" developed by [[Edwin Link]], thus becoming the world's first [[aquanaut]].<ref name="Marion">{{cite book |first=Marion Clayton |last=Link |title=Windows in the Sea |publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution Press]] |location=Washington, D.C. |year=1973 |isbn=0-87474-130-0 |lccn=72-93801}}</ref><ref name="Ecott">{{cite book |first=Tim |last=Ecott |title=Neutral Buoyancy: Adventures in a Liquid World |publisher=[[Atlantic Monthly Press]] |location=New York |year=2001 |pages=249–250 |isbn=0-87113-794-1 |lccn=2001018840 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=5Dw7htaxwtUC&pg=PA250}}</ref><ref name="Norton">{{cite book |first=Trevor |last=Norton |title=Underwater to Get Out of the Rain: a love affair with the sea |publisher=[[Da Capo Press]] |year=2006 |page=191 |isbn=0-306-81487-0 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=iPdIMTqBFGgC&pg=PA191&lpg=PA191&dq=robert+stenuit+ocean+biography&source=web&ots=lj5SPsCoIK&sig=3DbF9Mp4JMa2x4HjpuooEbqLOag }}</ref> [[File:Spanish Galleon.jpg|thumb|200px|Spanish galleon]]
== Early career == Sténuit began [[spelunking]] at the age of seventeen. He discovered [[underwater diving|diving]] in 1953, when he began [[scuba diving]] in [[cave diving|flooded caves]] in Belgium. He subsequently became interested in [[speleology]], and went on to spend many years exploring the [[Caves of Han-sur-Lesse]].<ref name="Sténuit 2">{{cite book |first=Robert |last=Sténuit |title=The Deepest Days |others=Trans. Morris Kemp |publisher=[[Coward-McCann]] |location=New York |year=1966 |lccn=66-10428}}</ref><ref name="Sténuit 3">{{cite book |author=Stenuit, Robert with Jasinski, Marc |title=Caves and the marvellous world beneath us |others=Trans. Harry Pearman |publisher=[[Alfred Smith Barnes|A.S. Barnes and Company]] |location=New York |year=1966}}</ref>
Sténuit had a passion for history. At the age of 20, after reading ''600 Milliards Sous les Mers'' by [http://classicdivebooks.customer.netspace.net.au/oeclassics-a-rieseberg.html Harry Reiseberg], a work of fiction about [[shipwrecks]] and treasure diving, Sténuit left the [[Free University of Brussels]], where he was studying [[political science|political]] and [[diplomacy|diplomatic science]] in preparation for a career as a lawyer.<ref name="Sténuit 1"/><ref name="Immersed">{{cite journal |first=Sean |last=Holland |title=Salvor, Archeologist Robert Sténuit |journal=Immersed |issue=032 |pages=10–11, 14–16 |year=1999 |url=http://www.nothingtosea.com/docs/immersed_rs.pdf |accessdate=August 30, 2011}}</ref> In 1954 Sténuit began looking for the treasures of the [[Spanish treasure fleet|Spanish fleet]] sunk in 1702 at the [[Battle of Vigo Bay]] by English and Dutch warships. He searched without success, finding only modern wrecks.<ref name="Immersed"/><ref name="Footnote 1">''Treasures of the Armada'' (Sténuit), p. 143.</ref><ref name="Footnote 2">According to Holland, Sténuit began cave diving in 1952 and treasure hunting in Vigo Bay in 1953.</ref>
Together with another sunken treasure hunter, the American John Potter, Sténuit worked for the Atlantic Salvage Company, Ltd. on the specially-equipped vessel ''Dios Te Guarde'' for search and recovery of underwater [[treasure]], beginning another search for the wrecks of the 1702 Plate Fleet, which lasted two years.<ref name="Sténuit 2"/><ref name="NGM 1">{{cite journal |author=Lord Kilbracken |authorlink=John Godley, 3rd Baron Kilbracken |date=May 1963 |title=The Long, Deep Dive |journal=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]] |volume=123 |issue=5 |pages=718–731 |publisher=[[National Geographic Society]] |location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>
Robert Sténuit worked as a professional diver for the French company SOGETRAM (Société Générale de Travaux Maritimes et Fluviaux), but eventually left SOGETRAM to become the chief diver for Edwin Link's Man in Sea project.<ref name="Immersed"/><ref name="HDS">{{cite web |title=Historical Diving Society – In Memory of Andre Galerne |first=Christopher |last=Swan |date=October 15, 2009 |url=http://www.hds.org/InMemory/AG/AndreGalerne.html |publisher=[[Historical Diving Society]] USA |accessdate=August 30, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927002931/http://www.hds.org/InMemory/AG/AndreGalerne.html |archivedate=September 27, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
== Man in Sea project == From September 6–10, 1962, Sténuit participated in Man in Sea, Edwin Link's first experiment with an [[underwater habitat]], which was performed with a submersible decompression chamber (SDC) at [[Villefranche-sur-Mer]] on the Mediterranean, at a depth of 200 feet (62 m).<ref name="Marion"/><ref name="Sténuit 2"/><ref name="Immersed"/><ref name="NGM 1"/><ref name="LinkColl">{{cite web |url=http://library.binghamton.edu/specialcollections/findingaids/linkcoll_m3.html |title=Edwin A. Link 1904–1981 |first1=Martha |last1=Clark |first2=Jeanne |last2=Eichelberger |accessdate=August 26, 2011 |publisher=[[Binghamton University#Facilities and places|Binghamton University Libraries]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317171710/http://library.binghamton.edu/specialcollections/findingaids/linkcoll_m3.html |archivedate=March 17, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> While submerged in the cylinder, Sténuit breathed a [[helium]]-[[oxygen]] mixture ([[Heliox]]). The experiment was conducted from Link's [[yacht]], the ''Sea Diver''.<ref name="Marion"/><ref name="Sténuit 2"/><ref name="Immersed"/><ref name="NGM 1"/> Sténuit remained on the sea floor for over 24 hours, becoming the world's first aquanaut.<ref name="Marion"/><ref name="Ecott"/><ref name="Norton"/><ref name="Sténuit 2"/><ref name="NGM 1"/><ref name="LinkColl"/>
During this dive, a [[mistral (wind)|mistral]] sank the ''Reef Diver'', the ''Sea Diver'''s launch, which was carrying fifteen bottles of helium.<ref name="Marion"/><ref name="Sténuit 2"/><ref name="NGM 1"/> A mistral surge also caused the cylinder to float back to the surface, where Sténuit remained safe from [[decompression sickness]] because the cylinder was still pressurized. A [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] boat brought an additional supply of helium during the night of September 7–8, allowing Sténuit to continue to be supplied with helium while [[decompression (diving)|decompressing]].<ref name="Marion"/><ref name="Sténuit 2"/>
Edwin Link's second Man in Sea experiment was conducted in June–July 1964 in the [[Berry Islands]] (a chain in the [[Bahamas]]) with Sténuit and [[Jon Lindbergh]], one of the sons of [[Charles Lindbergh]], who made the first solo nonstop flight across the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]]. Sténuit and Lindbergh stayed in the SPID habitat (Submersible, Portable, Inflatable Dwelling) for 49 hours underwater at a depth of 432 feet, breathing a helium-oxygen mixture.<ref name="Marion"/><ref name="Sténuit 2"/><ref name="LinkColl"/><ref name="NGM 2">{{cite journal |last=Link |first=Edwin A. |authorlink=Edwin Albert Link |date=April 1965 |title=Outpost Under the Ocean |journal=National Geographic |volume=127 |issue=4 |pages=530–533 |publisher=National Geographic Society |location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref><ref name="NGM 3">{{cite journal |first=Robert |last=Sténuit |date=April 1965 |title=The Deepest Days |journal=National Geographic |volume=127 |issue=4 |pages=534–547 |publisher=National Geographic Society |location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref><ref name="MacInnis">{{cite book|first=Joe|last=MacInnis|authorlink=Joseph B. MacInnis|title=Underwater Man|year=1975|publisher=[[Dodd, Mead & Company]]|location=New York|pages=53–68|isbn=0-396-07142-2|lccn=75000680}}</ref> Dr. [[Joseph B. MacInnis]] participated in this dive as a [[life support]] specialist.<ref name="Marion"/><ref name="Sténuit 2"/><ref name="NGM 3"/><ref name="MacInnis"/> At the end of the two divers' decompression, a ''Sea Diver'' crew member and Sténuit's wife, Annie Sténuit, sustained minor injuries when the end of an air tank blew off. Sténuit, who had developed a case of [[Decompression sickness|the bends]] during decompression, still had some lingering symptoms afterwards in his shoulders and ankles, but these eventually dissipated.<ref name="Hellwarth">{{cite book|last=Hellwarth|first=Ben|title=Sealab: America's Forgotten Quest to Live and Work on the Ocean Floor|location=New York|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|year=2012|pages=102–103|isbn=978-0-7432-4745-0|lccn=2011015725|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V4sbNMwQJI4C&pg=PT102}}</ref>
In 1965, the Man in Sea project was taken over by a new company, [[Ocean Systems Inc.]]<ref name="Sténuit 2"/><ref name="Immersed"/><ref name="LinkColl"/> Link departed from the project, but Sténuit remained as a researcher, adviser and development engineer, conducting test dives in [[decompression chamber]]s and underwater habitats and computing new helium-oxygen [[decompression table]]s for greater depths.<ref name="Sténuit 2"/><ref name="Immersed"/> In 1966, Ocean Systems established an office in London with Sténuit in charge. His professional work at this time involved drilling on off-shore [[Oil platform|oil and gas rigs]] in the [[North Sea]], but in his spare time he began researching the wreck of the Spanish [[galleass]] ''[[Girona (ship)|Girona]]''.<ref name="Immersed"/><ref name="Footnote 3">''Treasures of the Armada'' (Sténuit), p. 145.</ref>
== Underwater archeologist == Sténuit became involved with [[underwater archeology]] and the search for [[shipwrecks]], collaborating with [[Henri Delauze]] (president of [[Compagnie maritime d'expertises|COMEX]]).<ref name="Immersed"/><ref name="NGM 4">{{cite journal |first=Robert |last=Sténuit |year=1969 |title=Ireland's Rugged Coast Yields Priceless Relics of the Spanish Armada |journal=National Geographic |volume=135 |issue=6 |pages=745–777 |publisher=National Geographic Society |location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref><ref name="Footnote 4">''Treasures of the Armada'' (Sténuit), pp. 7, 170–171.</ref><ref name="NGM 5">{{cite journal |first=Robert |last=Sténuit |year=1975 |title=The Treasure of Porto Santo |journal=National Geographic |volume=148 |issue=2 |pages=260–275 |publisher=National Geographic Society |location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref> In 1968, Sténuit created the "Groupe de Recherche Archéologique Sous-Marine Post-Médiévale" (Group for Underwater Post-Medieval Archaeological Research), or "GRASP". GRASP has managed the inventory of 17 merchant shipwrecks and a number of warships from the 16th century through the 19th century.<ref name="ISC"/><ref name="Immersed"/>
Sténuit's most important underwater archaeological discoveries are:
* Recovery of underwater treasures of the [[galleass]] ''[[Girona (ship)|Girona]]'', part of the [[Invincible Armada]]. (1967)<ref name="ISC"/><ref name="Immersed"/><ref name="NGM 4"/><ref name="Footnote 5">''Treasures of the Armada'' (Sténuit), ''passim''.</ref> * ''Slot ter Hooge'', a [[Dutch East India Company|Dutch East Indiaman]] carrying a large quantity of gold and silver coins and [[bullion]], which wrecked in 1724 near the [[Madeira Islands]]. (1975)<ref name="ISC"/><ref name="Immersed"/><ref name="NGM 5"/><ref name="AEI">{{cite web |url=http://www.artifactexchange.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=58&Itemid=106 |title=Slot ter Hooge |year=2008 |accessdate=August 24, 2011 |publisher=Artifact Exchange International |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926005900/http://artifactexchange.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=58&Itemid=106 |archivedate=September 26, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * The ''Witte Leeuw'' wreck, part of a [[convoy]] carrying spices and [[Ming Dynasty|Ming]] [[porcelain]]. (1977)<ref name="ISC"/><ref name="Wreck Site">{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?116285 |title=Witte Leeuw [+1613] – WRECK SITE |date=January 3, 2009 |last=Lettens |first=Jan |accessdate=August 24, 2011}}</ref><ref name="VOC">{{cite web |url=http://www.vocsite.nl/schepen/detail.html?id=11720 |title=De VOCsite : gegevens VOC-schip Leeuw, Witte 1601 |accessdate=August 24, 2011 |publisher=de VOCsite}}</ref>
Robert Sténuit is the author of several books on diving and underwater archeology translated into several languages. Currently, he remains an active seeker of underwater treasures' location and identification, especially in wrecks of ships that belonged to the various East India companies. He continues to direct GRASP alongside his daughter, [[archeologist]] Marie-Eve Sténuit.<ref name="ISC"/>
== Books == * ''Ces mondes secrets où j'ai plongé'' (''These secret worlds where I dived'') – [[Robert Laffont]] * ''L'or noir sous les flots bleus'' (''The black gold in the blue waters'') – [[Dargaud]] * ''Histoire des pieds lourds'' (''History of heavy feet'') – Musée du scaphandre * ''Les épaves de l'or'' (''The wrecks of gold'') – [[Gallimard]] * ''Dauphin mon cousin'' (''The dolphin, cousin to man'') – [[Le Livre de poche]] * ''La plongée sous-marine, vacances chez Neptune'' (''Scuba diving, holidays with Neptune'') – Dargaud * ''Le livre des trésors perdus'' (''The book of lost treasures'') – Famot * ''Les trésors de l'Armada'' (''Treasures of the Armada'') – [[Albin Michel]] * ''Les jours les plus profonds'' (''The deepest days'') – [[Plon (publisher)|Plon]] * ''L'or à la tonne: l'exploitation des trésors engloutis'' (''The gold per tonne: exploitation of sunken treasure'') – [[Glénat (publisher)|Glénat]] * ''La flûte engloutie'' (''The sunken flute'') – Plon * ''Merveilleux monde souterrain'' (''Caves and the marvellous world beneath us'') – [[Hachette (publisher)|Librairie Hachette]]

The '''Society of Biblical Literature''' ('''SBL'''), founded in 1880 as the '''Society of Biblical Literature and Exegesis''',<ref>{{cite book | last = Cutter | first = Charles | title = Judaica Reference Sources | publisher = Libraries Unlimited | location = Littleton | year = 2004 | isbn = 1-59158-133-8 |page=102}} "Society of Biblical Literature The Society of Biblical Literature was founded in 1880 "to advance the public understanding of the Bible and biblical scholarship."</ref> is an American-based [[learned society]] dedicated to the academic study of the [[Bible]] and related ancient literature. Its current stated mission is to "foster biblical scholarship". Membership is open to the public, and consists of over 8,500 individuals from over 80 countries.<ref>[http://www.sbl-site.org/membership/default.aspx SBL membership], Society of Biblical Literature</ref> As a scholarly organization, SBL has been a constituent society of the [[American Council of Learned Societies]] since 1929.<ref>[http://www.acls.org/sbibllit.htm SBL] @ American Council of Learned Societies official site.</ref>
==History== The eight founders of The Society of Biblical Literature and Exegesis first met to discuss their new society in [[Philip Schaff]]'s study in New York City in January 1880. In June the group had their first Annual Meeting with eighteen people in attendance. The new society drew up a constitution and by-laws and discussed several papers. Membership dues were set at three dollars. By the end of the year, membership had grown to forty-five and publication of the meeting proceedings were in the planning stages. The Journal of Biblical Literature (JBL) was launched the following year.<ref>Saunders, Ernest W. ''Searching the Scriptures: A History of the Society of Biblical Literature, 1880-1980''. SBL Biblical Scholarship in North America 8. Chico, CA: Scholars Press, 1982. {{ISBN|978-0891305910}}</ref> The SBL was not the first association dedicated to biblical studies in North America, but it was the first that was interdenominational.<ref>Frank Ritchel Ames, Charles William Miller ''Foster Biblical Scholarship: Essays in Honor of Kent Harold Richards'' 2010 p68 "The Society of Biblical Literature was not the first association dedicated to the study of the Bible in North America, but it was the first group that was both interinstitutional and interdenominational. To be sure, it was dominated by ..."</ref> The thirty-two founding members of SBL in 1880 even included a [[Unitarianism|Unitarian]], Ezra Abbott.<ref>Richard Thomas Hughes ''The American quest for the primitive church'' 1988 p90 "The Society of Biblical Literature was founded in America in 1880. Of the thirty-two founding fathers only one – Ezra Abbott – was a Unitarian, and he was educated at Bowdoin and self- trained in biblical criticism.41 Five of the fathers ..."</ref> The society's development was contemporary with increasing interest in [[Ancient Near East]] studies.<ref>William Rainey Harper, Ernest De Witt Burton, Shailer Mathews ''The Biblical world'' 1912 p39 "In the same year in which the Society of Biblical Literature was founded [[Francis Brown (theologian)|Francis Brown]] began to offer courses in Assyrian at [[Union Theological Seminary in the City of New York|Union Seminary]]. Rightly to appreciate the progress made in the last thirty years we should have to review the ..."</ref>
== Leadership == [[Gale A. Yee]] was elected as Vice-President of the Society of Biblical Literature in 2018 and will become President of the organization in 2019.
==Publications== The Society of Biblical Literature has published the flagship ''[[Journal of Biblical Literature]]'' since 1881. In addition it publishes the journal ''Review of Biblical Literature''. It publishes literature under the imprint SBL Press".<ref>[https://www.sbl-site.org/publications/default.aspx SBL Press Homepage]</ref>
''The SBL Handbook of Style'' is a style manual specifically for the field of ancient Near Eastern, biblical, and early Christian studies. ''The SBL Handbook of Style'' includes a recommended standard format for abbreviation of Primary Sources in Ancient Near Eastern, biblical, and early Christian Studies.<ref>''The SBL Handbook of Style '', ed. Society of Biblical Literature (2nd ed.; Atlanta: SBL Press, 2014).</ref> ''The Chicago Manual of Style'' (16th ed.) refers writers to ''The SBL Handbook'' "for authoritative guidance".<ref>''The Chicago Manual of Style'' (16th ed.; Chicago, IL: University of Chicago Press, 2010, §§ 10.45 and 14.252) {{ISBN|0226104206}}</ref> ''The Student Supplement'' is downloadable, and also contain recommendations for [[transliteration]] standards.<ref>[https://www.sbl-site.org/assets/pdfs/pubs/SBLHSsupp2015-02.pdf Student Supplement to "The SBL Handbook of Style", second edition] pdf</ref>
In 2011 the society was awarded a $300,000 grant from the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] to produce [[Bible Odyssey]], "an interactive website that brings nonsectarian biblical scholarship to the general public".<ref>[http://www.neh.gov/news/archive/April2011grantsStatebyState.pdf NEH gov April 2011 grants State by State]</ref><ref>http://www.bibleodyssey.org</ref>
In 2016, the Society of Biblical Literature published a jobs report in conjunction with the [[American Academy of Religion]] that provided employment data from the 2014-15 academic year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbl-site.org/careercenter/hiring-trends.aspx|title=SBL Career Center|website=www.sbl-site.org|access-date=2017-11-29}}</ref>

Atlanta, GA: Society of Biblical Literature, 2010. {{ISBN|978-1-58983-534-4}} *Attridge, Harold W., and James C. VanderKam (eds). SBL Biblical Scholarship in North America 22. Atlanta, GA: Society of Biblical Literature, 2006. {{ISBN|1-58983-259-0}} *Saunders, Ernest W. {{refimprove|date=May 2017}} '''Victor Erle Nash-Williams''' (21 August 1897 – 15 December 1955) was a noted [[Welsh people|Welsh]] [[archaeologist]].
On the death of his father, Albert Henry Williams, his mother, Maude Rosetta (née Nash) Williams, formally adopted the surname "Nash-Williams".<ref name="DWB">{{cite web|url=http://wbo.llgc.org.uk/en/s2-NASH-ERL-1897.html|title=NASH-WILLIAMS, VICTOR ERLE|author=George Counsell Boon|website=Dictionary of Welsh Biography|publisher=National Library of Wales|access-date=3 May 2017}}</ref> Educated at the [[Lewis School, Pengam]], and at the [[Cardiff University|University College]] in Cardiff, Victor Erle Nash-Williams was appointed Keeper at the [[National Museum of Wales]] in succession to [[Cyril Fox]].<ref name="DWB"/> His work involved the excavation of a [[Roman villa]] at [[Llantwit Major]], catalogues of the inscribed and sculptured stones at [[Caerleon]] and at [[Caerwent]], a book on [[Wales in the Roman Era|Roman Wales]], ''The Roman Frontier in Wales'' (1954) and his magnum opus, ''The Early Christian Monuments of Wales'' (Cardiff, 1950). He was editor of ''[[Archaeologia Cambrensis]]'' from 1950 to 1955.
His brother, Alvah Harry Nash-Williams, was a well-known author of school [[Latin]] textbooks, and his son, [[Crispin Nash-Williams|Crispin St. John Alvah Nash-Williams]], a prominent mathematician.
A monument to his efforts can be seen at the [[Roman Legionary Museum]] in [[Caerleon]].
